column8: The India national cricket team is also known as Team India and Men in Blue. India is ranked first in Tests, second in ODIs and second in T20Is by the ICC. Virat Kohli is the current captain of the team, while the head coach is Ravi Shastri.

column26: The Wankhede Stadium in Mumbai has been host to numerous high-profile cricket matches in the past, most notable being the 2011 Cricket World Cup Final, in which India defeated Sri Lanka by 6 wickets. The stadium witnessed the last match of Sachin Tendulkar's international career.
column30:
The advent of One Day International (ODI) cricket in 1971 created a new dimension in the cricket world. India began as a weak team in ODIs and did not qualify for the second round in the first two editions of the Cricket World Cup.

However, under the captaincy of Kapil Dev, India won the Cricket World Cup in 1983, defeating the favourites and the two-time defending champions West Indies in the final at Lords, owing to a strong bowling performance.
column33: The 1983 Cricket World Cup (officially the Prudential Cup '83) was the 3rd edition of the Cricket World Cup tournament. It was held in England and Wales and was won by India.
column37: Kapil Dev captained the Indian cricket team that won the 1983 Cricket World Cup. He was named by Wisden as the Indian Cricketer of the Century in 2002.
column45: India and Pakistan jointly hosted the 1987 World Cup, the first time that the competition was held outside England. They again jointly hosted the 1996 World Cup with Sri Lanka. Sachin Tendulkar and Anil Kumble joined the national side in 1989 and 1990 and further improved the team. However, the team was damaged in 2000 when Mohammed Azharuddin and Ajay Jadeja were implicated in match fixing and given bans.

column8: The Royal Challengers Bangalore are a franchise cricket team based in Bangalore, Karnataka, that plays in the Indian Premier League (IPL)

column30:

column45:
In the 2011 auction, Royal Challengers retained only one of their players, Virat Kohli. West Indian batsman Chris Gayle and South African batsman AB de Villiers was brought in.

In the 2011 season, The Royal Challengers qualified for the finals but lost to Chennai at their home ground.

In the 2012 season, a batting failure at Hyderabad in RCB’s final game of the season led to the end of the team’s campaign, making it the first time since 2009 that they failed to qualify for both the play-offs and the Champions League.

In the 2013 season, they again did not qualify for the playoffs.

In the 2014 season, they ended up 7th in the points table and didn't qualify for the playoffs.

In the 2015 season, they lost to the Chennai Super Kings in the Qualifier 2, and ended the season finishing third.

In the 2016 season, they played the final against SRH, again in Bengaluru. RCB lost a hard fought match by 8 runs, to end as runners up in this ninth season of the IPL.

In the 2017 season, they ended up at the bottom of the table with 10 losses and 3 wins.

In the 2018 season, they did not advance to the playoffs.

column8: The Australia national cricket team is the joint oldest team in Test cricket history, having played in the first ever Test match in 1877.
column26: The Melbourne Cricket Ground (MCG), also known simply as "The G",[4] is an Australian sports stadium located in Yarra Park, Melbourne, Victoria. Home to the Melbourne Cricket Club, it is the 10th largest stadium in the world, the largest in Australia, the largest in the Southern Hemisphere, the largest cricket ground by capacity, and has the tallest light towers of any sporting venue.
column30: The Australian cricket team participated in the first Test match at the MCG in 1877, defeating an English team by 45 runs, with Charles Bannerman making the first Test century, a score of 165 retired hurt.
column45: The so-called 'Golden Age' of Australian Test cricket occurred around the end of the 19th century and the beginning of the 20th century, with the team under the captaincy of Joe Darling, Monty Noble and Clem Hill winning eight of ten tours
column60: The 1930 tour of England heralded a new age of success for the Australian team. The team, led by Bill Woodfull – the "Great Un-bowlable" – featured legends of the game including Bill Ponsford, Stan McCabe, Clarrie Grimmett and the young pair of Archie Jackson and Don Bradman.
column75: The team continued its success after the end of the Second World War, with the first Test (also Australia's first against New Zealand) being played in the 1945–46 season against New Zealand. Australia was by far the most successful team of the 1940s, being undefeated throughout the decade, winning two Ashes series against England and its first Test series against India.
column89: David Andrew Warner (born 27 October 1986) is an Australian international cricketer and a former captain of the Australian national team in limited overs cricket
column92: Glenn Donald McGrath was a fast-medium pace bowler and is considered one of the greatest bowlers in cricketing history

column8: The England cricket team represents England and Wales in international cricket. England and Australia were the first teams to play a Test match in 1877
column26: Widely referred to as the Home of Cricket,  it is the home of Middlesex County Cricket Club, the England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB), and the European Cricket Council (ECC).
column30:
The first overseas tour occurred in September 1859 with England touring North America. This team had six players from the All-England Eleven, six from the United All-England Eleven and was captained by George Parr.

The first Test match on English soil occurred in 1880 with England victorious; this was the first time England fielded a fully representative side with W.G. Grace included in the team
column45: The 1970s, for the England team, can be largely split into three parts. The early 70s saw Ray Illingworth's side dominate world cricket. The mid-1970s were more turbulent. England were badly exposed as ageing and lacking in good fast bowling against the 1974–75 Australians, losing that series 4–1 to lose the Ashes. The side of 1977–80 contained some young players who went on to become England greats,
column60:
Michael Vaughan took over, with players encouraged to express themselves. England won five consecutive Test series prior to facing Australia in the 2005 Ashes series, taking the team to second place in the ICC Test Championship table.

The 2009 Ashes series featured the first Test match played in Wales, at Sophia Gardens, Cardiff. England drew the match thanks to a last wicket stand by bowlers James Anderson and Monty Panesar. A victory for each team followed before the series was decided at The Oval. Thanks to fine bowling by Stuart Broad and Graeme Swann and a debut century by Jonathan Trott, England regained the Ashes.
column75:
England won their first ever ICC world championship, the 2010 World Twenty20, with a seven-wicket win over Australia in Barbados..

After finishing as runners-up in the ICC Champions Trophy, England faced Australia in back-to-back Ashes series. A 3–0 home win secured England the urn for the fourth time in five series. However, in the return series, they found themselves utterly demolished in a 5–0 defeat, their second Ashes whitewash in under a decade
column89: He is is currently vice-captain of the England cricket team.

column8: The West Indies cricket team, traditionally known as the Windies, is a multi-national cricket team representing the Anglophone Caribbean region and administered by Cricket West Indies. The players on this composite team are selected from a chain of fifteen Caribbean territories
column26: The Queen's Park Oval has hosted more Test matches than any other ground in the Caribbean and first hosted a Test match in 1930. The ground is considered one of the most picturesque venues in the world of cricket, featuring the view Trinidad's Northern Range.
column30:
The history of the West Indies cricket team began in the 1890s, when the first representative sides were selected to play visiting English sides. The WICB joined the sport's international ruling body, the Imperial Cricket Conference, in 1926, and played their first official international match, granted Test status, in 1928.

The West Indies defeated England for the first time at Lord's on 29 June 1950 and, on 16 August 1950, completed a 3–1 series win when they won at The Oval. Although
column45: By the late 1970s, the West Indies led by Clive Lloyd had a side recognised as unofficial world champions, a reputation they retained throughout the 1980s.[19] During these glory years, the West Indies were noted for their four-man fast bowling attack, backed up by some of the best batsmen in the world. They won the first 2 world cups.  The 1980s saw them set a then-record streak of 11 consecutive Test victories in 1984, which was part of a still-standing record of 27 tests without defeat (the other tests being draws).
column60: Throughout the 1990s and 2000s, West Indian cricket declined, largely owing to the failure of the West Indian Cricket Board to move the game from an amateur pastime to a professional sport. Victory in the 2004 Champions Trophy and a runner-up showing in the 2006 Champions Trophy left some hopeful, then they beat Australia and then host Sri Lanka in the 2012 World Twenty20 to win their first ICC world championship since the 1979 World Cup and then bested England to win the 2016 World Twenty20, making them the first team to win the World Twenty20 twice
column89: Both World T20s were won with Sammy as captain, making him the only West Indian captain besides Clive Lloyd with multiple ICC tournament victories.

column105: The 2015 Cricket World was the first and to date the only Cricket World Cup Afghanistan has participated in. Afghanistan was grouped with hosts Australia and New Zealand.
column109: Afghanistan won the tournament, beating the West Indies in the final. Afghanistan's Mohammad Shahzad was named the player of the match.

column8: The Bangladesh national cricket team, popularly known as "The Tigers", is administered by the Bangladesh Cricket Board (BCB). Bangladesh is a full member of the International Cricket Council (ICC) with Test and One Day International (ODI) status.
column26: The Sher-e-Bangla National Cricket Stadium (SBNCS), also called Mirpur Stadium, is a cricket ground in Dhaka, the capital of Bangladesh. The ground holds approximately 25,000 people. The venue was taken over by the Bangladesh Cricket Board in 2004, as the home of both the men's and women's national teams.
column30: In 1972, the government created the Bangladesh Cricket Board, then called the Bangladesh Cricket Control Board, with a directive to organise cricket in the new country.
column45: The first full international team to visit Bangladesh was Sri Lanka in January 1978. Sri Lanka was then close to ICC Full Member status (achieved in 1982) and their higher standard was underlined by a series of innings victories in the three international matches against Bangladesh.
column60: Pakistan visited Bangladesh for the first time. It was eight years after the end of the Liberation War but tensions were still evident.
column75: The Bangladesh team played in the Cricket World Cup for the first time, having qualified by winning the 1997 ICC Trophy, for the 1999 tournament in Great Britain.
column89: In April 2019, he was named as the captain of Bangladesh's squad for the 2019 Cricket World Cup.
column92: Shakib Al Hasan is a Bangladeshi international cricketer who currently captains the Bangladesh national team in Test and T20I formats. He is considered as the best and greatest cricketer to have ever played for Bangladesh.
column95: Mohammad Mushfiqur Rahim is a Bangladeshi cricketer and the former captain of the Bangladesh national cricket team.He holds the record for highest score by a test Bangladesh batsman.
column98: Muhammad Tamim Iqbal Khan is a Bangladeshi international cricketer. A left-handed opening batsman, he is the Bangladeshi's most successful runscorer to date.
column101: They appeared for the first time in World Cup in the 1999 Cricket World Cup as an associate team.
column105: Bangladesh enjoyed a good tournament with two great wins against India and South Africa.
column109: Bangladesh was a co-host with India for the 2011 Cricket World Cup.
column113: Shakib Al Hasan became the first player in history to hold the number 1 positions in all three formats of cricket, in the all-rounder category on 12 January 2015.

column8: The Sri Lanka national cricket team, nicknamed The Lions, represents Sri Lanka in international cricket. It is a full member of the International Cricket Council (ICC) with Test, One-Day International (ODI) and T20 International (T20I) status.
column26: Galle International Stadium is a cricket stadium in Galle, Sri Lanka, situated near the Galle fort and fringed on two sides by the Indian Ocean. It is considered to be one of the most picturesque cricket grounds in the world.
column30: Renamed Sri Lanka in 1972, the national team first competed in top level international cricket in 1975, when they played against West Indies during 1975 Cricket World Cup
column45: After Sri Lanka was awarded Test status in 21 July 1981 as eighth Test playing nation, they had to wait until 6 September 1985, where Sri Lanka recorded their first Test win by beating India
column60: Sri Lanka had to wait for more than 7 years for their next series victory, which came against New Zealand in December 1992.
column75: Sri Lanka have registered more wins against Pakistan and Bangladesh than any other team, with 14.
column89: Separamadu Lasith Malinga bowls right-arm fast-medium and, is commonly used as a specialist death bowler, which lead to his nicknames, "Slinga Malinga" and "Malinga the Slinga".
column92: Chandimal holds the joint record for taking the most number of catches in a single T20I as a fielder.
column95: Angelo Davis Mathews, is a professional Sri Lankan cricketer and a former captain in all formats.
column98: Thisara Perera, is a professional Sri Lankan cricketer. He was purchased by the Chennai Super Kings for US$50,000 in the auction for the 2010 Indian Premier League.
column101: Winners of the 1996 Cricket World Cup, which they co-hosted with India & Pakistan
column104: Winners of the 2002 ICC Champions Trophy
column105: Joint winners of the 2002 ICC Champions Trophy, which they also hosted in their own right
column109: Runners up in the 2007 Cricket World Cup, hosted by the West Indies
column113: Runners up of the 2011 Cricket World Cup, which they co-hosted with India & Bangladesh.

column8: The South African national cricket team, nicknamed the Proteas is administered by Cricket South Africa. South Africa is a full member of the International Cricket Council (ICC) with Test, One Day International (ODI) and Twenty20 International (T20I) status.
column26: The Wanderers Stadium is a stadium situated in Johannesburg, South Africa. Test, One Day and First class cricket matches are played here.
column30: The oldest cricket club in South Africa is the Port Elizabeth Cricket Club, founded in 1843.
column45: Sir Donald Currie sponsored the first English team to tour South Africa.
column60: The South African cricket team toured Australia for the first time in 1910–11.
column75: As of 15 March 2018, the ICC ranks South Africa second in Tests, second in ODIs and seventh in T20Is, as well as sixth in the women's overall championship
column89: Hashim Mohammad Amla is a South African international cricketer who plays for South Africa in all three formats of the game. He is a right-handed batsman and holds the record for the highest individual Test score of any South African batsman.
column92: Quinton de Kock is a South African professional cricketer. He also plays for Mumbai Indians in Indian Premier League. He was named the Cricketer of the Year at Cricket South Africa's 2017 Annual Awards.
column95: David Miller is the former captain of the Kings XI Punjab in the Indian Premier League (IPL) and represents South Africa in both One Day Internationals (ODIs) and Twenty20 Internationals.
column98: Jean-Paul Duminy, often shortened to JP Duminy, is an international South African cricketer. He is vice-captain of the South Africa T20I team. He plays for the IPL cricket team Mumbai Indians.
column101: South Africa won the 1998 ICC Champions Trophy
column105: South Africa hosted the 2003 Cricket World Cup

column8: The New Zealand national cricket team, nicknamed the Black Caps, played their first Test in 1930 against England in Christchurch, becoming the fifth country to play Test cricket.
column26: Eden Park is New Zealand's largest sports stadium, located in central Auckland, New Zealand. It is used primarily for cricket in summer.
column28: Beginnings of cricket in New Zealand
column30: The first recorded game of cricket in New Zealand took place in Wellington in December 1842.
column45: New Zealand played its first two internationals (not Tests) in 1904–05 against a star-studded Australia team
column60: In 1927 New Zealant toured England. They played 26 first class matches, mostly against county sides.
column75: New Zealand played its first matches against the West Indies in 1951–52, and Pakistan and India in 1955/56.
column89: Martin James Guptill, is a New Zealand international cricketer who plays as an opening batsman. Guptill holds the current record for the highest individual score in Cricket World Cup matches.
column92: Colin Munro is a South-African born New Zealand international cricketer. He is the first player to score three Twenty20 International centuries.
column95: Kane Stuart Williamson (is a New Zealand international cricketer who is currently the captain of the New Zealand national team and Sunrisers Hyderabad in the Indian Premier League. He is considered as one of the best batsmen in the world.
column98: Taylor is considered as one of the greatest batsmen to represent New Zealand and became the nation's highest ODI century maker in 2017, with his 17th ODI century.
column101: New Zealand were hosts and semi finalists of the 1992 Cricket World Cup
column105: New Zealand went through to the semifinals and placed 3rd overall.
column109: New Zealand was runner's up in the 2009 ICC Champions Trophy
column113: New Zealand was Runners-up at the 2015 Cricket World Cup.

column8: The Delhi Capitals are a franchise cricket team that represents the city of Delhi in the Indian Premier League (IPL).
column26: The Feroz Shah Kotla Ground is a cricket ground located at Bahadur Shah Zafar Marg, New Delhi. It was established in 1883 and is the second oldest international cricket stadium still functional in India.
column30: Delhi Daredevils had a good run in the inaugural edition of the IPL.They lost to eventual champions Rajasthan Royals in the semi final.
column45: Despite dominating for the regular season, the Daredevils crumbled in the semi-final under a fierce batting by Aussie keeper Adam Gilchrist, who hit the joint 5th fastest fifty in IPL history (just 17 balls).
column60: The Delhi Daredevils lost all first six matches of IPL 2013 and won their first match in seven games against the Mumbai Indians.
column75: After losing their first match against the two-time Champions Kolkata Knight Riders, they went on to dominate Kings XI Punjab, Royal Challengers Bangalore, Defending Mumbai Indians, Kolkata Knight Riders in the second leg and newcomers Gujarat Lions.
column89: In August 2013, Shikhar Dhawan recorded the then-second-highest individual score in a List A match when he scored 248 runs off 150 balls for India A against South Africa A at Pretoria
column92: Colin Munro is a South-African born New Zealand international cricketer, who plays limited overs formats of the game.  He is the first player to score three Twenty20 International centuries.
column95: Kagiso Rabada (born 25 May 1995) is a South African international cricketer who plays all formats of the game. Rabada, who is known by the nickname KG became the first cricketer to win six awards at Cricket South Africa's (CSA) annual dinner, including the prize for Cricketer of the Year in 2016.
column98: Trent Alexander Boult is a New Zealand international cricketer who plays as a bowler.  He was the joint leading wicket taker at the 2015 Cricket World Cup.
column101: Placed 4th at the 2008 Indian Premier League
column105: Delhi Capitals were 3rd in the 2009 Indian Premier League
